en-us.description: the study of physical remains, and things that people made and used in the past

a way of measuring how far north or south a point is on the globe, with the equator around the middle as the starting point; the equator is at 0 degrees, while the north pole is 90 degrees north and the south pole is 90 degrees south
an object of cultural or historical interest that was made by a human
the sum of all numbers in a quantitative dataset, divided by how many there are
a display that uses bars to show counts or proportions in each category
the study of living things (plants and animals)
one that classifies and for which arithmetic does not make sense
things made from clay hardened by heat
the science of identifying and understanding what physical substances are made of
a Chinese ship with sails that are supported with parallel wooden strips
an instrument that uses magnetism to show directions, starting with north
the tendency to continue to believe the same things over time, and not believe new ideas that are different
the number of items in a certain category
the quality of happening over and over again in a regular pattern
the science of collecting, organizing, and drawing general conclusions from data, with the help of computers
pieces of categorical or quantitative information about a group of individuals or things
a type of ceramics made near Hebei, China from about 1000 to 1300 CE; because they were usually baked upside-down, the rim of Ding bowls were usually unglazed and banded with metal
the material in living things that has information about how they will develop, passed on from one generation to the next
a time period when a particular family was in power, handing down control from one generation to the next
a setting where people mainly are surrounded with beliefs and opinions that are like their own
half of a circular ball shape; the earth’s globe can be divided into northern and southern hemispheres, or eastern and western hemispheres
stylized picture of an object representing a word, syllable, or sound, as found in ancient Egyptian, the Maya calendar, and other writing systems.
an oven used to heat ceramic pottery to high temperatures, which makes them last a long time
a display that uses lines to show how values of a quantitative variable change over time

a way of measuring how far east or west a point is on the globe, with Greenwich, England as the starting point; halfway around the world from Greenwich would be where 180 degrees east meets 180 degrees west
having to do with the sea
the act of determining someone’s geographical position and the route to follow to reach a destination
coming from living things
a value in a quantitative dataset that is unusually low or high compared to the rest of the values
a display that uses a circular pie’s slices to show proportions in each category
the chance or likelihood of happening, usually reported as a percentage
a fraction, decimal, or percent that equals count divided by total
the Chinese dynasty of emperors that ruled from 1636 to 1912 CE
a type of ceramics made in China from about 1000 to 1300 CE; their basic color was white but often with a pale green glaze
one that has numeric value for which arithmetic makes sense
a way of estimating the age of materials that came from living things, based on how much regular and radioactive carbon they contain
a sticky substance that comes from trees and may be burned for fragrance when it hardens
a soft silvery metal
what is left after a ship sank at sea; the contents can teach us about what was valued and traded at the time.
an expert on human societies, past and present
factors relating to someone’s social and financial position, such as their education and income
the Chinese dynasty of emperors that ruled from 960 to 1279 CE
the Chinese dynasty of emperors that ruled for most of the years between 618 and 907 CE
a characteristic that can be different for different individuals
a hard silver-gray metal
